intro: Picris comosa, commonly known as the common wormwood, is a flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is an annual herb that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, branching stems and grayish-green leaves with a distinctive, aromatic scent. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in flat-topped clusters, which bloom from late spring to early autumn. It thrives in dry, disturbed soils and is often found along roadsides and in meadows. The plant is known for its medicinal properties and has been used historically in herbal remedies.
